H0.text: What color changes can be observed is what the student is trying to determine by placing a chemical in an insulated container, measuring its temperature, adding a second chemical, sealing the container, and monitoring the temperature.

H1.text: How much precipitate is formed is what the student is trying to determine by placing a chemical in an insulated container, measuring its temperature, adding a second chemical, sealing the container, and monitoring the temperature.

H2.text: Heat absorbed or released is what the student is trying to determine by placing a chemical in an insulated container, measuring its temperature, adding a second chemical, sealing the container, and monitoring the temperature.

H3.text: "How can this reaction be reversed?" is the question the student is trying to answer by placing a chemical in an insulated container, measuring its temperature, adding a second chemical, sealing the container, and monitoring the temperature.

A4.text: The enthalpy change Î”H for a reaction is equal to the heat q transferred out of (or into) a closed system at constant pressure without in- or output of electrical energy.

A5.text: Heat production or absorption in a chemical reaction is measured using calorimetry, e.g. with a bomb calorimeter.
